en_first_half: Once again the sense of helplessness assailed him. He knew, or he could imagine, the arguments which proved his own nonexistence; but they were nonsense, they were only a play on words. Did not
en_second_half: the statement, “You do not exist,” contain a logical absurdity? But what use was it to say so? His mind shriveled as he thought of the unanswerable, mad arguments with which O’Brien would demolish him.
en_results_raw: The philosophers and skeptics who claimed that his thoughts and feelings were merely a product of a brain in a vat, a cleverly constructed illusion designed to deceive him into believing in a reality that was not truly his own. He thought of the countless times he had woken up in the morning, feeling the warmth of the sun on his skin, the softness of the bed beneath him, and the gentle rustle of the leaves outside his window. He thought of the people he had loved and lost, the memories they had shared, and the laughter they had exchanged. And yet, he couldn't shake the feeling that it was all just a dream, a dream that could be shattered at any moment by the cold, harsh reality of his nonexistence. He felt like a puppet on a string, a marionette dancing to the tune of a master puppeteer who was pulling the strings from behind the scenes. He was trapped in a never-ending cycle of doubt and uncertainty, unable to escape the abyss of his own mind.

The board was cracked and the tiny wooden dice were so ill-cut that they would hardly lie on their sides. Winston looked at the thing sulkily and without interest. But then his mother lit a piece of candle and they sat down on the floor to play. Soon he was wildly excited and shouting with laughter as the tiddlywinks climbed hopefully up the ladders and then came slithering down the snakes again, almost back to the starting point.
